notes: With rising case counts, some states have paused or reversed opening plans. However, even these states still allow some non-essential businesses to operate (retail, personal care, etc) according to KFF and the NYT.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200708041430/https://www.kff.org/health-costs/issue-brief/state-data-and-policy-actions-to-address-coronavirus/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIh5-N1r6B6gIV3YVaBR3hIQbHEAAYAiAAEgJqUPD_BwE    https://web.archive.org/web/20200720071012/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/states-reopen-map-coronavirus.html

KFF reports that California has banned all gatherings, and that MN, NC, and MD have all banned gatherings of more than 10 people (10 people being allowed is currently coded as a level 4). However, several other states have lifted gathering restrictions. This has led to cancellation of events exceeding this limit.    (use selection of 'large gatherings ban;)  https://web.archive.org/web/20200708041430/https://www.kff.org/health-costs/issue-brief/state-data-and-policy-actions-to-address-coronavirus/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIh5-N1r6B6gIV3YVaBR3hIQbHEAAYAiAAEgJqUPD_BwE

Congress is set to discuss new COVID-19 aid package, stimulus this week with input from the president. An aid package has already passed the house.      https://web.archive.org/web/20200720174747/https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/20/treasury-yields-investors-monitor-us-coronavirus-cases-stimulus-talks.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20200720175014/https://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/top-republicans-meet-with-trump-to-negotiate-next-coronavirus-stimulus-package
